What you've done so far has changed it temporarily.
When you reboot, the resolution changes will be lost.
Yeah, but the newmode line goes first.
Then, in that file, there should be a section that starts with #Add your own lines here...
Put the newmode line right under that and the addmode line under the newmode line.
You should try gksudo gedit /etc/X11/xinit/xinitrc <-- Som1 help me edit this
Sorry, try putting it right above the last line.
but how do i edit it ?
I think I finally found where I put mine.
There should be a line not too far down in the file that says "/sbin/initctl -q emit login-session-start DISPLAY_MANAGER=gdm"
Put the two lines (newmode then addmode) right *above* that line.
And make sure to use /usr/bin/xrandr instead of xrandr for both lines.
So, it should go /usr/bin/xrandr --newmode blah blah blah; /usr/bin/xrandr --addmode blah blah blah; /sbin/initctl blah blah blah.
Oh, no. usr as the actual word usr without an e.
ok Olathe  should i give an enter after it ?
Yep. Make sure blah blah blah is replaced with the stuff you had before.
should i try with a restart ?
Once you have it, go ahead and copy the contents of the file to a pastebin.
OK, one more thing. Right on the line after addmode, put /usr/bin/xrandr --output VGA1 "1280x1024_60.00"
So, you should have newmode, addmode, output all one after the other.
I think that should be it, but I want to make sure.
OK, go ahead and save that.
And your monitor is running nicely in 1280x1024 at the moment, right?
OK, go ahead and restart. It should have the right resolution either right away or after you login.
If it doesn't, let us know.
